1. Hemoglobin is a protein in red blood cells that carries oxygen throughout the body. It is a chemical compound made up of four subunits: two alpha subunits and two beta subunits.
2. Anti-human globulin and monospecific IgG reagents are both chemical compounds used in blood testing. Anti-human globulin is a serum that contains antibodies that bind to human red blood cells, while monospecific IgG reagents are used to detect the presence of specific antibodies in the blood.
3. Polyspecific IgG reagents are also chemical compounds used in blood testing. They are made up of a mixture of antibodies that bind to different antigens on the surface of red blood cells.
